page.title: 08WYCOMBE'S CHAIR INDUSTRY
page.content: { High Wycombe}is famous for it's{chair {industry}which has developed over{200 {years. Beech trees}grow well in the Chiltens because they like chalky soil and the{bodgers}used these to make chair legs. During the 18th bodgers lived among the trees in the woods around Wycombe in their huts turning chair legs. They used a{pole lathe, driven by a young larch pole. The legs were taken to{factories}where the framer fitted together the part which make up the chairs. About 1790 the early factories came into being and by the{mid-nineteenth century}there were about a hundred furniture factories in Wycombe. We still have many furniture firms The best known are{Parker Knoll, {Ercol}and{Gommes. The{Chair Museum}tells the{history of {chair making}around Wycombe, with many tools,and a{Bodger's hut.
